body:
@jralfonsog 

I'm not an expert at Docker but it looks like you need to specify the host DNS such as `127.0.0.1:5000` if the hosts are sitting on the same host.

When specifying a tracking_uri, it can be a URL such as `http://localhost:5000`. [set_tracking_uri Documentation](https://www.mlflow.org/docs/latest/python_api/mlflow.html#mlflow.set_tracking_uri)

`http://mlflow` is not a valid URL.

Hi, @andychow-db . Thanks for your response.

"mlflow" is the name of the docker host, so http://mlflow:5000 should be the right URL. Actually, I found that the snippet works if the variable `experiment` corresponds with an existent run, but if doesn't if I the `experiment` doesn't exist yet. Does it make any sense?

Oh interesting! That's a great find. 

It looks like MLflow fails out when we try to create a new experiment when it does not exist. (https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/master/mlflow/tracking/fluent.py#L47-L51)

I think the next step is to look at the MLflow server's logs to see what caused the INTERNAL_ERROR. Would you mind pulling those logs?

I cleaned up the logs a bit and pulled out what I thought was interesting: 

```
2020/04/14 08:23:21 ERROR mlflow.server: Exception on /api/2.0/mlflow/experiments/create [POST]"
Traceback (most recent call last):"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/flask/app.py\", line 2447, in wsgi_app"
    response = self.full_dispatch_request()"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/flask/app.py\", line 1952, in full_dispatch_request"
    rv = self.handle_user_exception(e)"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/flask/app.py\", line 1821, in handle_user_exception"
    reraise(exc_type, exc_value, tb)"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/flask/_compat.py\", line 39, in reraise"
    raise value"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/flask/app.py\", line 1950, in full_dispatch_request"
    rv = self.dispatch_request()"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/flask/app.py\", line 1936, in dispatch_request"
    return self.view_functions[rule.endpoint](**req.view_args)"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/server/handlers.py\", line 102, in wrapper"
    return func(*args, **kwargs)"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/server/handlers.py\", line 149, in _create_experiment"
    request_message.artifact_location)"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/store/file_store.py\", line 235, in create_experiment"
    return self._create_experiment_with_id(name, str(experiment_id), artifact_location)"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/store/file_store.py\", line 211, in _create_experiment_with_id"
    write_yaml(meta_dir, FileStore.META_DATA_FILE_NAME, experiment_dict)"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/utils/file_utils.py\", line 128, in write_yaml"
    if not exists(root):"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/utils/file_utils.py\", line 31, in exists"
    return os.path.exists(name)"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/genericpath.py\", line 19, in exists"
    os.stat(path)"
TypeError: stat: path should be string, bytes, os.PathLike or integer, not NoneType"
WARNING:root:Malformed experiment '1'. Detailed error Yaml file '/opt/mlruns/1/meta.yaml' does not exist."
Traceback (most recent call last):"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/store/file_store.py\", line 193, in list_experiments"
    experiment = self._get_experiment(exp_id, view_type)"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/store/file_store.py\", line 247, in _get_experiment"
    meta = read_yaml(experiment_dir, FileStore.META_DATA_FILE_NAME)"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/utils/file_utils.py\", line 159, in read_yaml"
    raise MissingConfigException(\"Yaml file '%s' does not exist.\" % file_path)"
mlflow.exceptions.MissingConfigException: Yaml file '/opt/mlruns/1/meta.yaml' does not exist."
WARNING:root:Malformed experiment '1'. Detailed error Yaml file '/opt/mlruns/1/meta.yaml' does not exist."
Traceback (most recent call last):"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/store/file_store.py\", line 193, in list_experiments"
    experiment = self._get_experiment(exp_id, view_type)"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/store/file_store.py\", line 247, in _get_experiment"
    meta = read_yaml(experiment_dir, FileStore.META_DATA_FILE_NAME)"
  File \"/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/utils/file_utils.py\", line 159, in read_yaml"
    raise MissingConfigException(\"Yaml file '%s' does not exist.\" % file_path)"
mlflow.exceptions.MissingConfigException: Yaml file '/opt/mlruns/1/meta.yaml' does not exist."
```
Thanks, @andychow-db . What should be the next step? Shouldn't this be created when generating a new experiment?

I am able to run your code as long as the name of the experiment is unique. 
Reusing the same name gives the API error you mentioned.

Simple test - in your code, change the name to:
import sys
EXPERIMENT_NAME = sys.argv[1]

And call then call the script by adding `uuid` at the end. (sudo apt install uuid , if you do not have it)
Sorry for the late response. Please, let me give it a look and come back here. Thanks for the idea

Looking at the stacktrace, looks like we call `write_yaml` [here](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/v1.3.0/mlflow/store/file_store.py#L211) with a `meta_dir` that is `None`. AFAICT the only way this can happen is if `mkdir` returns `None` [here](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/v1.3.0/mlflow/store/file_store.py#L205), which only seems possible if `self.root_directory` is `None` in the `FileStore`. Thus I suspect the command in your dockerfile for running the server may not actually be setting the backend store URI of the server properly - are you able to create/view any experiments under your server?

> I am able to run your code as long as the name of the experiment is unique.
> Reusing the same name gives the API error you mentioned.
> 
> Simple test - in your code, change the name to:
> import sys
> EXPERIMENT_NAME = sys.argv[1]
> 
> And call then call the script by adding `uuid` at the end. (sudo apt install uuid , if you do not have it)

Naming the experiment with uuid, the problem remains in my case :/



> Looking at the stacktrace, looks like we call `write_yaml` [here](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/v1.3.0/mlflow/store/file_store.py#L211) with a `meta_dir` that is `None`. AFAICT the only way this can happen is if `mkdir` returns `None` [here](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/v1.3.0/mlflow/store/file_store.py#L205), which only seems possible if `self.root_directory` is `None` in the `FileStore`. Thus I suspect the command in your dockerfile for running the server may not actually be setting the backend store URI of the server properly - are you able to create/view any experiments under your server?

I am able to view an existent experiment from before (I am using a volume for the "experiment" folder which already has a run from before this setup), but I can't create a new one because each time I try it gives the error.

@jralfonsog I was able to run the following on Jupyter using your docker-compose.yml:

```
mlflow.set_tracking_uri(os.environ["MLFLOW_TRACKING_URI"])
mlflow.set_experiment("iris_classification")
```

And suddenly, after all this time... it works now! I have an EXT4 unit for Linux, a NTFS for Windows, and a bigger NTFS shared one (where I had placed the project). Turns out that I was having some kind of permission problems, and they were solved by moving it to the EXT4. I can't believe it...

Thanks a lot to everyone for your time. I guess you can close this issue now.
@jralfonsog Awesome! Can we close this issue?

Yes! I had just edited my message to say so :)

Thanks again!
